hints_html:
Use the integral comparison test, i.e. find an integrand g(x) such that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{e^{-x}}{2x-1} \leq g(x) \quad \text{and}\quad \int_1^\infty g(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

converges.

sols_html:
On the interval \([1,\infty)\) we have that 2x-1 \(\geq\) 1 and so

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{e^{-x}}{2x-1} \leq e^{-x}\end{aligned}\]

for all x \(\geq\) 1. Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^\infty \frac{e^{-x}}{2x-1}\,dx \leq \int_1^\infty e^{-x}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

by the integral comparison test. Since the latter integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^\infty e^{-x}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

converges (see lecture notes or direct calculation), the former integral also converges, by the integral comparison test.
